The study consists of three trials using a different type of auditory cue for each trial. Participants used their typical screen readers for all tasks. For the first test, participants were provided with a pregenerated block of source code and were thentasked with finding a specific block in the code using the auditory cues available. Comprehensive Literature Review (CLR) of existing data from traditional literature review sources, blog posts, email list threads, and observations from our previously published research.

CLR is a systematic approach to establishing a literature review from multiple sources as a methodology. Here, we have employed a CLR to bring together multiple viewpoints that may not be present in a traditional literature review. The process includes traditional literature searches (books, articles, proceedings, etc.) and involves expanding the search to include one or more MODES (Media, Observation, Documents, Experts), before final analysis and synthesis of information

We emailed a study packet to each participant consisting of a study application and a cursor tracking script. The study application presented a series of methods to the participant inside of a Notepad session and prompted them to submit their summaries and any comments in a separate window. The application terminated after one hour and took the participant to an exit survey.

Literature REview
This paper reports on a review of accessibility research efforts geared towards making programming and programming environments accessible to professional programmers with visual impairments and students with visual impairments learning how to code. This includes work that seeks to investigate and understand accessibility barriers as well as research efforts that propose solutions to overcome these barriers and make programming friendlier to people with visual impairments
